summary:
Yiddish is a Germanic language with Hebrew and Slavic influences, historically spoken by Ashkenazi Jews. It originated in Central Europe and was written using the Hebrew alphabet. Before World War II, millions spoke Yiddish, but the Holocaust led to a significant decline. Today, it's mainly spoken in Hasidic communities, with around 600,000 speakers worldwide.

The language has two main forms: Eastern (more common) and Western, each with various dialects. Yiddish is still used in religious and social settings by Haredi Jews and has influenced culture, including cooking and music.
title: Yiddish
